The training of Royal Engineers who are preparing for disaster relief work is different from their military training for combat. While there are some similarities, such as physical fitness and teamwork, the focus of the training is different.

In combat training, Royal Engineers focus on developing skills that are necessary to support military operations, such as constructing defensive or offensive structures, laying mines, and constructing bridges under fire. The training is designed to prepare soldiers for high-intensity combat scenarios, where their lives and those of their comrades are at risk.

In contrast, the training for disaster relief work is aimed at preparing soldiers to react effectively in disaster zones and in support of other humanitarian organizations. They are trained to identify the most pressing needs of affected communities, provide emergency shelter, clean water, and sanitation, clear roads and open new access routes, as well as protecting the health of affected populations.

The training for disaster relief work also focuses on community relations and cultural sensitivity. Disaster relief work often involves working closely with local communities, which can have their own customs, languages, and cultural practices.

In summary, while there are similarities between the training for disaster relief work and combat training, there are significant differences in the focus and scope of the training. Disaster relief training aims to develop skills that are specific to humanitarian support and working with communities, while combat training focuses on developing skills that are relevant for military operations.
